content: The Act titled "Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006" amends the findings of the Belarus Democracy Act of 2004, highlighting the government's violations of human rights and democratic principles, particularly in the flawed presidential and parliamentary elections of 2006. The Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006 criticizes Belarus for failing to meet OSCE commitments for democratic elections, arbitrary use of state power, and widespread detentions. The regime of Aleksandr Lukashenka maintained power through an illegal referendum, abolishing the parliament and extending his term. The government has not made credible efforts to solve cases of disappeared opposition figures. The Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006 criticizes the Lukashenka regime for failing to address the disappearances of opposition figures and for imprisoning political activists. Hundreds of pro-democratic activists have faced harassment and jailings, particularly after the flawed 2006 presidential elections. The Lukashenka regime in Belarus has maintained a monopoly over information, targeting independent media and suppressing freedom of speech. They have also cracked down on civil society, harassing and closing NGOs and trade unions. Minority religious communities face harassment and restrictions on their practices. The Belarusian authorities have attempted to silence dissent through retribution against activists, including threats, firings, expulsions, beatings, and intimidation. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to call for the immediate release of political prisoners and support democracy, human rights, and the rule of law in Belarus. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 aims to support democracy, human rights, and the rule of law in Belarus, preserve the country's independence and sovereignty, promote democratic movements to end tyranny, reject flawed elections, and work with other countries for Belarus' integration into the European community of democracies. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 aims to support democracy, human rights, and the rule of law in Belarus, promote democratic movements, and integrate Belarus into the European community of democracies. Amendments include supporting freedom, democracy, human rights, fair and transparent elections, and developing a democratic political culture and civil society. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 aims to support democracy, human rights, and civil society in Belarus. Amendments include expanding independent media, aiding civil society development, and supporting human rights defenders. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to support independent trade unions, human rights defenders, democratic political parties, and transparent electoral processes. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include television broadcasting to Belarus and update sanctions against the government.
